explanation: Predictions are based on trends across the lanthanide oxychlorides in the provided dataset (LaClO, CeClO, PrClO, SmClO, etc.). Lattice parameters follow the lanthanide contraction: a (and b) decrease slowly from La → Pr → Nd → Sm, and c shows a mild decrease as well. PrClO (a=4.08497, c=6.82919, V≈113.96) and SmClO (a=3.98835, c=6.73221, V≈107.09) bracket Nd; CeClO (a≈4.0572) is also a close neighbour. I therefore place NdClO between Pr and Ce/Sm, choosing a ≈4.06 Å and c ≈6.86 Å (tetragonal a=b), giving a volume ≈113.1 Å^3. Formation energies for LnClO compounds cluster around −3.4 to −3.6 eV/atom (LaClO −3.6046, PrClO −3.4535, SmClO −3.4896); I pick a value near the series average, −3.48 eV/atom. Most LnClO entries are large-gap insulators (band gaps ~4–5 eV) except Ce (0 eV) and a few anomalies; Pr and Sm have gaps ~4.7–4.9 eV, so NdClO is predicted to be an insulator with a gap around 4.6 eV.

NdClO is expected to follow the lanthanide-contraction and electronic trends seen for neighboring LnClO compounds (CeClO, PrClO, SmClO, LaClO). Lattice parameters for the series show a ≈ b in the 3.9–4.12 Å range and c ≈ 6.7–6.95 Å, with volumes around 107–117 Å^3. Nd, lying between Pr and Sm, should have a slightly smaller a than Pr and slightly larger than Sm; I interpolate a/b ≈ 4.045 Å and c ≈ 6.85 Å (volume ≈ 112 Å^3). Formation energies per atom for nearby LnClO compounds cluster near −3.4 to −3.6 eV/atom; NdClO is predicted near the series mean, ≈ −3.48 eV/atom. Many light/mid lanthanide chloroxy compounds (La, Pr, Sm) show substantial band gaps (≈4–5 eV) except Ce/Eu which are metallic; Nd is expected to be insulating with a large gap similar to Pr/Sm, so I predict a band gap ≈4.6 eV. These values are interpolative estimates based on the provided analogous data and known lanthanide trends; actual DFT/experimental results may differ due to f-electron localization and possible magnetic states.

Predictions based on the Nd oxyhalide analogues in the dataset (particularly NdBrO, NdSeF, NdSF). NdBrO (a≈4.028 Å, c≈7.899 Å, band gap 4.483 eV, formation energy ≈-3.284 eV) is the closest chemical analogue. Replacing Br with the smaller, more electronegative Cl is expected to slightly contract the lattice (smaller a and c) and to maintain or slightly increase the electronic gap (greater ionic character). The formation energy per atom should remain in the same strongly negative range as other Nd oxyhalides (≈-3.2 to -3.4 eV/atom). The cell is assumed to keep the same structure type (a=b), so I scale a and c down modestly from the NdBrO values to produce the volume estimate.

Predictions are based on nearby Nd-based layered/quasi-tetragonal oxy-/chalcogen/halide analogues in the supplied dataset (notably NdSF, NdSeF, EuClF and NdTeCl). These compounds show systematic trends: replacing smaller anions (O, F) with larger anions (S, Se, Te, Cl) increases a and c and generally reduces the band gap and makes formation energies slightly less negative. NdClO (an oxychloride) is expected to be relatively compact (a ~4.0 Å, c ~7.0 Å) and chemically stable (formation energy per atom similar to other Nd–chalcogen/halide layered compounds ~ -3.2 to -3.5 eV/atom). Its band gap should be moderate (smaller than the sulfide but larger than the telluride chloride analogues), so I predict a sub‑1 eV to ~1 eV gap. The lattice parameters/volume estimate is the average of the NdSF/NdSeF and EuClF type values, adjusted for Nd ionic radius.

NdClO is a lanthanide oxyhalide. I used trends among Ln–O–halide analogues in the dataset (La/Pr/Sm/Ho/Er BrO and related oxyhalides): (1) lanthanide contraction reduces a across the series (La -> Pr -> Nd -> Sm), (2) smaller halides (Cl vs Br) give slightly smaller a and c than the corresponding BrO phases, and (3) lanthanide oxyhalides are wide-gap insulators with large negative formation energies (~-3.0 to -3.4 eV/atom). Placing Nd between Pr and Sm and accounting for Cl being smaller than Br yields a,b slightly below the BrO values and c modestly reduced, giving volume ~125 Å^3. The band gap is set near other Ln oxyhalides (~4 eV) and the formation energy near -3.3 eV/atom as observed for La/Pr/Sm oxyhalides in the table.

NdClO is a lanthanide oxyhalide structurally similar to the rare-earth chloride/fluoride entries in the provided dataset (e.g., SmClF, EuClF, YbClF). Those compounds have relatively small tetragonal unit cells (a ≃ 3.65–3.90 Å, c ≃ 8.9–9.5 Å) and strongly negative formation energies (~ -2.7 to -3.5 eV/atom). Nd3+ has an ionic radius slightly larger than Sm3+, and O2- is similar to or slightly larger than F-, so I expect a modestly larger cell than SmClF. Many of the lanthanide halide/oxyhalide entries in the dataset are metallic (reported band gap = 0.0 eV), so I assign a zero gap (likely metallic or very small gap). Given these trends, I predict a tetragonal cell with a=b ≈ 3.72 Å, c ≈ 8.98 Å (volume ≈ 124.3 Å^3) and a formation energy similar to other Ln halide/oxyhalides, about -2.95 eV/atom.

Predicted by analogy with other Nd-based layered pnictide/chalcogen/halide compounds in the dataset (notably NdSF and NdSeF). NdSF (a=3.942 Å, c=6.929 Å, band gap ~1.24 eV, formation energy ~-3.35 eV/atom) and NdSeF (a=4.036 Å, c=7.158 Å, band gap ~0.92 eV, formation energy ~-3.23 eV/atom) bracket the expected behavior. Replacing S/F by Cl/O is expected to give lattice parameters intermediate between the S/F and Se/F cases (O is smaller than S/Se, Cl is larger than F), and O-containing compounds tend to be strongly bound, so formation energy should be comparably negative. The band gap is expected to be between the NdSF and NdSeF values. Therefore I predict an intermediate a (≈3.99 Å) and c (≈7.05 Å), volume roughly a^2*c, a band gap around 1.05 eV, and a formation energy ≈-3.30 eV/atom.

NdClO is expected to adopt the layered PbFCl (P4/nmm)–type structure common to many rare-earth oxyhalides and chalcogen–halide REXY compounds in the training set. Analogues such as LaSF, CeSF and PrSF have a in the 3.88–4.05 Å range and c ≈ 6.9–7.0 Å; replacing S by the smaller O will tend to slightly reduce a, while replacing F by the larger Cl will increase c. That combination leads to an a near ~3.95–4.00 Å and a c increased to ~8 Å. RE-containing chalcogen/halide compounds in the set (LaSF, CeSF, ErSF, PrSF) show modest semiconducting gaps (~1.2–1.5 eV) and large negative formation energies (around −3 to −3.45 eV/atom for the sulfide–fluoride examples). Because Cl is less stabilizing than F the formation energy should be somewhat less negative than the most negative F-containing examples but still strongly negative due to O. Based on these analogues I predict a moderate semiconductor band gap and a formation energy comparable in magnitude to RE–S–F compounds but slightly reduced in magnitude.
